facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 79 of 1970 filed as appeal by special leave

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 79 of 1970. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 26, 1969 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 37 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 26, 1969 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 37 of 1965

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 26, 1969 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 37 of 1965. D. Karkhanis and S. P. Nayar, for the appellant.

facts.text: Relates to assessment of assessee for assessment year 1961-62, relevant previous year calendar year 1960

anchor.surface_text: HEGDE, J.-This is an appeal by special leave. It relates to the assessment of the assessee for the assessment year 1961- 62, for which the relevant previous year was the calendar year 1960.

facts.text: Assessee is a Tea Company

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a Tea Company. Upto the assessment year 1950-51 the Agricultural Income-tax Officer was accepting the companyputation of the, total income from the growth, manufacture and sale of tea made by the Income Tax Officer and taking 60 per cent of the income determined as the agricultural income under Rule 24 of the Income-tax Rules.

facts.text: Up to assessment year 1950-51, Agricultural Income-tax Officer accepted Income Tax Officer's computation of total income from tea and took 60% as agricultural income under Rule 24

anchor.surface_text: Upto the assessment year 1950-51 the Agricultural Income-tax Officer was accepting the companyputation of the, total income from the growth, manufacture and sale of tea made by the Income Tax Officer and taking 60 per cent of the income determined as the agricultural income under Rule 24 of the Income-tax Rules.

facts.text: From assessment year 1951-52, agricultural income-tax authorities took market value of thatch, bamboo and fuel grown in tea estate and used in tea business as 100% agricultural income, deducted cost of cultivation, taxed resulting income on market value basis

anchor.surface_text: On and from the assessment year 1951-52 the agricultural income-tax authorities started taking the market value of thatch, bamboo and fuel etc. grown in the tea estate and used in the tea business as 100 per cent agricultural income and after deducting the companyt of cultivation thereof, taxed the whole of the resulting income on the basis of the market value of those articles.

facts.text: From 1951-52, assessee had to pay on total income more than disclosed in Profit and Loss Account

anchor.surface_text: So, from that assessment year the companyputation of the total income from tea by the Income-tax authorities was varied by the Agricultural Income-Tax Officer and the assessee had to pay on a total income which was more than the income disclosed in the Profit and Loss Account.

facts.text: For 1961-62, assessee assessed to Income-tax under Rule 34 on profits per Profit and Loss Account with modifications by Income-tax Officer

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1961-62, the assessee companypany was assessed to Income-tax under Rule 34 of the Income-tax Rules, on its pronts as per its Pront and Loss Account with certain modifications, by the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: In expenses debited in accounts, only expenses for raising thatch, bamboo, fuel grown in tea estate and used in tea business were included

anchor.surface_text: In the expenses debited in Its accounts, only the expenses for raising thatch, bomboo, fuel etc. grown in the tea estate and used in the tea business were included.

facts.text: Assessee contended before Appellate Assistant Commissioner that market value of agricultural produce grown in tea estate and utilised in tea business, assessed 100% to agricultural income-tax, must be taken into consideration in computation of allowable expenditure

anchor.surface_text: Before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, the assessee raised the companytention that the market value of agricultural produce grown in the tea estate and utilised by the assessee in the tea business, which had been assessed at 100 per cent to agricultural income-tax, must be taken into companysideration in the companyputation of allowable expenditure.

facts.text: Reliance placed on decision in Dooars Tea Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: In support of that companytention reliance was placed on the, decision of this Court in the case of Dooars Tea Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, West Bengal 1 .

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner accepted assessee's contention and directed Income-tax Officer to modify assessment

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner accepted that companytention and directed the Income-tax Officer to modify the assessment accordingly.

facts.text: In Revenue's appeal, Tribunal accepted finding of Appellate Assistant Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by the Revenue the finding, of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was accepted by the Tribunal.

facts.text: At instance of Revenue, question referred to High Court

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter at the instance of the Revenue the following question was referred to the High Court for its opinion

facts.text: High Court answered referred question in affirmative and in favour of assessee

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered that question in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee. Hence this appeal by the Revenue.

facts.text: Real contention: whether assessee entitled to market value of agricultural produce grown by it but utilised for purpose of tea business

anchor.surface_text: The real companytention between the parties is whether the assessee is entitled to the market value of the agricultural produce grown by it but utilised for the purpose of tea business.

facts.text: In Dooars Tea Co. case, assessee grew bamboo, thatched grass, fuel timber etc. in estate and utilised for tea business

anchor.surface_text: The facts of that case are as follows The assessee, who is a tea grower, grew in its estate bamboo, thatched grass, fuel timber etc. and utilised the same for tea business.

facts.text: In Dooars, assessee contended only cost of growing produce should be considered, not market value, as used in own tea business; contention rejected by Revenue and upheld by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the assessees assessment under the Bengal, Agricultural Income-tax Act the assessee companytended that only the companyt of growing the produce in question should be taken into companysideration and number its market value as the same was used for the purpose of assessees tea business. This companytention was rejected by the Revenue and this Court upheld the decision of the Revenue.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Dooars held agricultural income computed on market value of bamboos, thatched grass, fuel timber per rule 4 of Bengal Agricultural Income-tax Rules

anchor.surface_text: This Court came to the companyclusion that the agricultural income should be companyputed on the basis of the market value of bamboos, thatched grass and fuel timber etc. in accordance with rule 4 2  of the Bengal Agricultural Income-tax Rules.

facts.text: Ratio of Dooars: not necessary that agricultural produce sold and profit made; sufficient if assessee gets benefit; tax market value of benefit received, not costs incurred for raising produce

anchor.surface_text: The ratio of that decision is that in the matter of companyputing the agricultural income it was number necessary that the agricultural produce should be sold and profit or gain made from such sale before it is companysidered as agricultural income. It is sufficient if the assessee gets any benefit from the same, and what is to be taxed is the market value of the benefit received by the assessee and number the companyts incurred by the assessee for raising the agricultural produce in question.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed Revenue's appeal with costs

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above this appeal fails and the same is dismissed with companyts.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 26, 1969 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 37 of 1965. D. Karkhanis and S. P. Nayar, for the appellant.
HEGDE, J.-This is an appeal by special leave. It relates to the assessment of the assessee for the assessment year 1961- 62, for which the relevant previous year was the calendar year 1960.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 26, 1969 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 37 of 1965. D. Karkhanis and S. P. Nayar, for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the assessees assessment under the Bengal, Agricultural Income-tax Act the assessee contended that only the cost of growing the produce in question should be taken into consideration and not its market value as the same was used for the purpose of assessees tea business.

concepts.unlisted_description: State law for taxing agricultural income

anchor.surface_text: This Court came to the conclusion that the agricultural income should be computed on the basis of the market value of bamboos, thatched grass and fuel timber etc. in accordance with rule 4 2 of the Bengal Agricultural Income-tax Rules.

concepts.interpretation: Requires computation of agricultural income on market value basis even for self-consumed produce

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ated to the levy of agricultural income-tax. The facts of that case are as follows The assessee, who is a tea grower, grew in its estate bamboo, thatc

concepts.unlisted_label: Rule 4 of the Bengal Agricultural Income-tax Rules
concepts.unlisted_description: Computation rule for agricultural income on market value

anchor.surface_text: The ratio of that decision is that in the matter of computing the agricultural income it was not necessary that the agricultural produce should be sold and profit or gain made from such sale before it is considered as agricultural income. It is sufficient if the assessee gets any benefit from the same, and what is to be taxed is the market value of the benefit received by the assessee and not the costs incurred by the assessee for raising the agricultural produce in question. It the assessee has to pay agricultural income-tax on the market value of the agricultural produce raised in his estate and used in his tea business it stands to reason that while determining the deductible expenditure incurred for the, purpose of his business, the same rule viz. the market value of the produce used for the tea business should be taken into consideration

concepts.interpretation: Extended to income-tax computation: market value of self-grown agricultural produce used in tea business is allowable as deductible expenditure, as it represents true economic cost

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: aken into companysideration and number its market value as the same was used for the purpose of assessees tea business. This companytention was reject

concepts.unlisted_label: Market Value Principle for Agricultural Income and Business Deductions
concepts.unlisted_description: Tax agricultural income and allow business deductions on market value of self-consumed produce providing economic benefit
